intro: Batschia conferta, commonly known as the clustered bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its compact growth habit and clusters of bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically blooms in late summer, producing blue to purple flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Batschia conferta thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or open habitats.
